metadata.synopsis: Lee Plenty (Christopher Scott Cherot) is a flailing, wannabe writer, homeless and apartment-sitting for his friend, the wealthy Havilland Savage (Chenoa Maxwell), while she is off visiting family. So Lee jumps at the chance to see Havilland, whom he has secretly loved for years, when he's invited to her New Year's Eve party. But the night leads to romantic complications that also involve Hav's recording-artist boyfriend, Michael Simmons (Hill Harper), and her sister, Leigh (Robinne Lee).

reviews: This all-black screwball comedy, about the fables and foibles of black middle-class urbanites, is well constructed, but it lacks style and polish to make it really work
Formulaic, but it has plenty to like.
Cherot's considerable charm as writer and star compensate for some rough patches.
Ah, love! Ah, black stereotypes! Why is it so hard to portray the black middle-class and the rich with any dignity?
What might seem cute when you're in the center of an exclusive coterie is simply noxious and monotonous onscreen.
an attempt at a modern screwball comedy involving several affluent African-Americans... though its heart is in the right place, 'Plenty' doesn't quite click...
It limps along at best. Its dialog is so stilted that the actors are content to read the screenplay rather than invest much energy in trying to act it.
